Hi to all, and welcome to new members.

A couple of things:

First, I am starting to implement surface chemistry in Cantera and 
wanted to give those of you who work with surface chemistry a chance 
for input. Let me know if you have opinions about the reaction rate 
formalism, support for coverage dependent rates, or anything else. 

Second, I wanted to give you a 'heads up' about what is coming soon. 
Within a couple of weeks I will be releasing a new Python version, 
and new one-dimensional reacting-flow models. With these you will be 
able to simulate

- flat premixed flames
- counterflow flames
- stagnation flows with surface chemistry


For a preview, see http://blue.caltech.edu/flame.ppt
This image shows two premixed, 1 atm, stoichiometric methane/air 
flames with different flowrates separated by 1 cm in a counterflow 
geometry. Velocity streamlines and CH are shown. This computation was 
done with GRI-Mech 3.0, and includes solving the energy equation. The 
final grid contained 70 or so points. It ran in a couple of minutes 
on a laptop.

Anyway, this should be out in a couple of weeks at the latest...

Dave
